I probably had over 300 hours into this game on the PSP version across a couple of different saves.  The PC port, aside from some resolution issues and somewhat clunky keyboard controls is basically the exact same game, with the one difference being that it comes with all the DLC previously released for the PSP version.  The actual story can probably be finished in 20-30 hours or so on a casual playthrough, but it's the post game where things start to get crazy.  Across the whole Disgaea series I'd say this might be the best compromise between accessibility and depth, as Disgaea 3 and later start to get much more complicated to figure out.  Even here expect to spend plenty of time on the Disgaea Wiki to figure out what's going on.

That said, once you get the flow down (and you can start turning off attack animations once you've had your fill) you get into a flow where you can start working your way through things at a pace that makes other strategy RPGs feel positively glacial in comparison.  After playing Disgaea games I have a really tough time trying to play something like Final Fantasy Tactics because it feels incredibly slow.

Oh, and I'd recommend playing with a controller if you have one.  Much smoother that way.

Hey, I dropped 500+ hours back in the day on the original Disgaea for my old PS2, so there's gotta be some appeal to it at least. I've been a gamer for a long time, having gotten my start playing all of the snes classic RPGs, so when I saw this game and its particular style, I brought it immediately. Being the type of player that enjoyed Lufia 2's ancient dungeon, and Star Ocean 2's Bonus dungeon's, I thought that I would really enjoy some of Disgaea's game mechanics -- in particular randomly generated item worlds, and the ability to level your characters well beyond the typical 99 cap (the cap in this game is literally 199000 levels....yes, you read that right).

Unfortunately, This is the most unnecessarily complicated game I have ever played in my life. There is simply too much going on to make it enjoyable. The game plays more like a single player MMO in terms of sheer grindiness, none of which is remotely necessary to complete the storyline. 

Pros:
Fun storyline and reasonable plot
Great voice acting (main character sounds like Goku)
Good music and graphics for the genre

Cons:
This game has everything and the kitchen sink thrown into it, and yet there isn't even that much variety. 
You can create as many characters as you want over a broad range of your typical RPG classes (thieves, knights, mages, etc). Each of those classes has multiple tiers that are unlockable through leveling. Each of those characters can be leveled to 199000, by repeatedly going to level 9999 and reincarnating back to level 1 again. Additionally, all characters can train in any of the 5 types of equipment (swords, bows etc), and gain skill levels (up to 255) that unlock new abilities. Those abilities can then be leveled up to 99 each. 
If all of the above wasn't enough, you will also level every single item in the game, from your lowly potions to your high level gear. In order to do that, you have to enter into the "item world" which is basically a RNG created world for that specific item. Items come in common (30 floors), rare (60 floors), and legendary (100 floors) qualities. Every 10 floors you have the chance to leave the dungeon. Every 30 floors there is a boss character. Each floor you complete adds a level to the item...though the max level for a legendary is actually 200, which you can get to by burning even more time in item world by going into "mystery gates" which are random encounters.
And if all that wasn't bad enough, items also have "specialists", which are 20 different types of souls that can by slotted into an item to provide additional benefits like raising stats. Sound easy? Nope. You have to level those too....up to level 20000 for a stat related soul. Oh and those souls have to be "subdued" so they can be transferred to other items....a process that consists of killing them in the item world. 
But wait! That's not all! In addition to the normal slog of killing things and leveling, most maps have what's known as "Geo Panels", which come with their own sets of effects. For instance, you could stand on a 20% damage panel and lose 20% of your health per turn. Now that doesn't sound so bad, except that you're going to be completing thousands of these floors, and you can't even autopilot. Even when your character is 1000x more powerful than the enemies you're encountering, you still have to pay attention, or else you might find yourself dead regardless. 

This whole game is a tireless, neverending slog which is almost entirely devoid of purpose. It's almost as if it was created solely to laugh at completionists/perfectionist players that want to maximise their gaming experience. Anyone who actually does it, after the thousands of hours it would take to achieve, has absolutely no life.

Well there, after I saw all the endings I guess it's time to write a review. I recommend this game to people who enjoyed the first Disgaea, Final Fantasy Tactics or any kind of grindy turn-based RPG. The game is a little bit too grindy for my taste, but later games in series make the process more enjoyable (they are yet to be ported though...).

In comparison with the first part of Disgaea series, it looks pretty solid. 

Gameplay contains much more features than the first one, which, however, are yet to be polished (in the next games that slowly make their way to PC users). Usage of monsters in your squad is more interesting than before (a pity that the brand-new mechanic starts working only after your first playthrough...)and special abilities make classes truly unique. New specialists are good and amount of skills is great. 

However, the gameplay contains some annoying features like (completely luck-based) farming for Treasure Maps to unlock an area with better stuff and, well, basically endgame content. Another one is 'Felony' system, which represent an interesting mechanic and has some entertaining cutscenes, but requires a little but too much effort to provide valuable results (also required to be used to have bad endings).

Plot-wise the game seems slightly inferior to the first game. The plot still contains a nice range of emotions (upbeat/cute/sad), but the scale is more shallow. In my opinion, it references (okay, simply uses) Etna and Laharl, a little bit too agressivly. The main rival, Axel, is rediculed way more than Mid-Boss/Vyers was in the first game and he fails to provide a nice impression, unlike Vyers, even though being mentioned for longer periods time - they needed 'Dark Hero Days' expansion, which allows us to play a story of Axel, to truly show us what a person he is. Endings are abundant, but only the main ending feels complete, while others leave an impression of being cut just after the culmination. The worst ending cuts back and provides some nightmare fuel, something that children of sin deserve <3

Music is still great. That's it, I highly recommend to listen to some heartwarming, cool, encouraging tracks: Cyber Dance, White Tiger, Sparkling (main ending ost), ETONA Rock, some others.

To be honest, I am not a perfectionist/completionist, I don't have enough love for grinding. It slightly spoils the endgame content for me since you just have to earn these sweet 9999 levels, Yosh*tsunas and so on, but I will probably try to complete this one.

31617134.review:
Disgaea is sort of like Final Fantasy in that it's a series of titles with their own stories and tales in each iteration. The difference being that Disgaea has character's that make cameos and/or play roles in the other titles (at least, thus far). Additionally, Disgaea keeps the same battle system and follows the incremental upgrade pathway for a series, whereby each following title improves on the last.

So nothing comes as a surprise here: Disgaea 2 follows the same conventions as Disgaea 1:

-Story mode is progressed through a Menu whereby each episode consists of 4 battle maps (varies, but typically 4) and upon completing the final one, a new episode is unlocked
-Everything you need to access (item dungeons, shops, etc) are all accessed from the hubworld; there is no open world exploration (or even linear world exploration) like most JRPG's
-New characters are unlocked/gained through regular progression in the story as well as character creation with mana attained from battles.
-No grinding is necessary to complete the story mode

Just as in 1 I love the streamlined manner in which story mode works. There's no long JRPG quest here; you just go straight into the battles with a short cutscene always proceeding it. There's no forgetting where to go next if you stop playing for a week or having to go grab items in several towns and dungeons to continue onwards with the story. The story itself is also a relatively light-hearted romp with a usually comedic tone.

The item world makes a comeback; the randomly generated maps whereby progression is done by getting to the exit. Included now are random encounters that occur without notice; enemies drop by the maps and you can either face them for good loot or just proceed to the next level of the map. They appear sparsely so facing them is always recommended, the problem is that as it's random the random encountered enemies might be leagues beyond your own level, making the whole ordeal moot. Given that these encounters rarely occur and some of the enemies carry items required to open optional maps in the story mode, some consistency would've been appreciated in their levels relative to the player's. There are also "mystery rooms" in the item world, which are alternate exits that take you to a dark room which either consists of merchants hawking rare wares, fights that will increase the items level, or treasure chests with items in them. Always recommended to go into the rooms unless you're not hurting for money, items, or planning on ditching the item after getting the specialists.

The Dark Assembly receives a rather large change; not only are the different bills you can pass more varied, but character unlocking is now done through the assembly itself. Whereas before unlocking new classes to create required meeting certain pre-requisites, now they've added the additional step of having to pass a bill allowing access to the class once the pre-requisite is met. Bills, as before, are passed through an assembly whereby you spend accumulated mana from battles to pass bills of varying costs; bills have an approval rate and if they fail you can eliminate senators unfavorable to your bill in a battle or just give up on the bill and attempt passing it later (spent mana is not recouped). 

The assembly itself requires less fighting than in the previous title. As senators will hate you more and more the more you fight them, it's not recommended to do so unless you're going to go level 1000 as many of these senators levels are in the hundreds. This penalty for fighting is a bit of a shame, as tossing no votes on top of higher levelled yes votes presented an enjoyable level of strategy; granted this is still possible but having hatred of your actions persist on the playthrough is a bit cumbersome and annoying when you just can't fight your way through a bill. Rather, gaining favor with senators and parties is the way to go now, which is certainly duller (and easier). It's not that an option was taken away, it's that it's not optimal now.

As for the fighting system: same old same old. Veterans will feel at home and it's as if nothing changed. The few differences are minimal: classes now have passive abilities unique to them that differentiate the classes more than just what weapon affinities they have. The series still requires a bit more differentiation between the classes to provide an impetus for creation past merely wanting to have every class in the game.

So past me giving out on a few points, is this an improvement over Disgaea 1? On a base level there is more here; so yes. But as the largest difference is the story and characterization, I'd have to say it's lower on the totem poll in that regard. Laharl, Etna, and Flonne made a good trio that often clashed. Here you have Rozalin and Adell which have an interesting dynamic as they are technically enemies working together, and for the manner in which the developers went about their relationship they deserve a thumbs up. Otherwise there's less laughter here; Tink is rather memorable as is Axel, but characters like Hanako and Taro are just there. The story was alright and had more "substance" than the "I wanna be the strongest!" plotline of Disgaea 1, but I still prefer the first games title as it still had multiple plotpoints occuring at once whereas here it's just Adell and Rozalin with the same goal of meeting Zenon. The fact that Etna steals the spotlight here even though she's not the MAIN character (albeit an important one) gives substance to the claim that the main cast from 1 was more memorable.

Sounds like I'm giving out about it, but the item world is still fun as hell, the grind is addictive *even though it isn't necessary*, which is almost paradoxical for anything with "RPG" in the title. You'll still waste inordinates amount of time going to the item world to level up equipment (every level traverssed increases item stats), and you'll be going to the item world to subdue specialists in the items themselves-which give a variety of effects and can be transferred to better items once subdued. I still spent more time doing things other than the story for no reason other than being addicted to moving specialists and strengthening equipment.

Final verdict? Good title albeit not as good in plot or characters *overall*. But on the game itself and the mechanics, more of the same and if you enjoyed it previously you'll enjoy it again. Just be sure not to play it directly after the first game.

[code] 魔王ゼノンの呪いにより人間が悪魔と化したヴェルダイムが舞台の本作。

以上が本編の導入部であり、様々な人間にスポットを当てたうえで「親子愛」や「兄弟愛」がこれ以降繰り広げられるわけだが、前作と比較するとややインパクトに欠ける印象を受けた。

主人公アデルは熱血漢かつ仲間想いの典型的な少年漫画キャラ、ロザリーは高飛車なお嬢様キャラでどこか既視感を覚える設定が多い。

彼はダークヒーローという特異なキャラ設定を持ち、一見人気者のようでありながら、実は落ちぶれた芸能人というギャップがたまらない。

今作ではプレネールとうさぎが予告編を担当しており、普通のニュース番組のように

レビュー記事を書いておいてなんだが、戦闘面では特に欠点は見つからないため、語ることはほぼない。

People say Disgaea is grindy, but what does that actually mean?

First off, I would say it's not grindy at all... if all you care about is beating the story (which is a good 30-40 hours of gameplay). The campaign is fun and well worth anyone's time. If you choose, you can overlevel your characters to have an easier time (it is really not necessary), but that can also suck the tension and fun out of the gameplay.  

If, however, you want to play the post game content (which is upwards of 100 hours of gameplay time), this is where you have to grind your ass off. Let me give you an example.

The true final boss of the game essentially requires you to have several perfect items equipped. To get a perfect item, you need to collect bonus levels while leveling up an item. The "mystery" (aka RNG) portal that gives bonus levels CAN (but doesn't always) spawn every 3 floors. Even if the portal does spawn, it  LIKELY DOES NOT contain the bonus levels you need. 

[u]What does this mean?[/u] It means that every 3 floors, you RESET THE GAME if you don't find your portal. If you find a portal, YOU RESET your game if it isn't one that gives bonus levels. To get a perfect item, you'll end up quitting and reloading the game upwards of 200 times. By the time you've beaten the true final boss of the game, you've reset thousands of times and there is simply *no way around that.* 

If you want to beat the post-game, you'll get really acquainted with this series of events: Menu, down down down down, quit game, yes, continue game, yes, talk to item worlder, enter item world, yes, check for portal, see that there in no portal, menu, down down down down, quit game, and repeat. You'll be doing that for hours. After a while your fingers hurt solely from resetting so much.

Does that sound like fun?

The true final boss of the game also requires you to have maxed out stats through leveling. Which means you'll be playing one map (Cave of Ordeals 4) over and over and over and over and over to level up, store somewhere between 6000-9999 levels, reincarnate to level 1, and do it again. 

Does that sound like fun?

Just know what you're getting into. Personally, I don't mind leveling in the manner I just described. It's definitely not ideal, but you do get to watch your numbers go up, and in true "role-play" fashion, it does feel like your character is actually training.  I *DO*, however, mind being forced to reset the game so often in order to actually complete it. It's poor design. What happened is that people basically broke the ps2 version of the game by forcing perfect items through resets, and to compensate they released a boss that requires perfect items in the PSP version of the game. This version.

Disgaea 1 did not require resets very often (just fringe cases of rarity matching and removing specialists). Having 100%'d both D1 and D2 here on steam, I can say that I enjoyed the post game a lot more in the first installment. 

I'm giving this game a lukewarm positive review because the story was fun the whole way through, and the post game has some decent content until you need to start perfecting stuff. I've read Disgaea 3 and upwards contain less of this "reset hell," so here's hoping.

7/10.

Серия [b]Disgaea[/b] на протяжении практически 15 лет является одной из лучших в жанре тактических RPG. Среди них можно встретить как номерные части, так и различные ответвления, приквелы, и даже визуальную новеллу. И можно с полной уверенностью отметить, что разработчик качественно проводит работу над ошибками. Каждая номерная часть привносит что-то новое в серию, развивая и улучшая уже имеющиеся идеи и концепцию.

Если вы знакомы с оригиналом, то вы наверняка помните о том, что во Вселенной [b]Disgaea[/b] существует множество миров. События второй части будут разворачиваться в местечке под названием [b]Veldime[/b], населенном людьми. Однако [b]Overlord Zenon[/b] все изменил в этом мире, страшное проклятие превратило всех его жителей в демонов, исказило их память, чувства и привычки, и только главный герой [b]Adell[/b] избежал этой участи, по неизвестным причинам. Он поклялся уничтожить злостного узурпатора, чтобы разрушить проклятие, и вернуть людям свой прежний облик. 

Можно провести определенную аналогию с первой частью, там мы могли наблюдать забавные взаимоотношения между [b]Laharl[/b], главным героем, и [b]Etna[/b] его помощницей. В [b]Disgaea 2[/b] также присутствует занятная парочка - [b]Adell[/b] и [b]Rozalin[/b], дочь того самого тирана-демона, наславшего злосчастное проклятие. [b]Disgaea[/b] - в первую очередь шикарные тактические возможности, которые представлены в виде разнообразного гринда, разноплановых бойцов, бесконечного множества генерируемых миров, прокачкой всего и вся, и многих прочих вкусностей, на описание которых не хватит и тысячи слов. Disgaea 2 is definitely an enjoyable experience if you're into story-driven games or JRPGs in general. However, there is very little (if any) in the way of open-world exploration, so if you're expecting something along the lines of Final Fantasy, you'll be disappointed. Equally, if you're not into combat or turn-based strategies, you should probably give it a miss; it's essentially all that the gameplay consists of.

While I seem to be ruling out a lot of people and insinuating that the game is niche, I actually think it's just the opposite; the story is much more interesting than many Western titles, and it's sprinkled with humour which will connect with both anime/JRPG fans and the uninitiated alike. Often, I found myself wanting to speed through the combat as quickly as possible (to the detriment of strategy and progress), just so that I could see what happens next.

 It's definitely worth a purchase if you like JRPGs and even turn-based strategies, and obviously, if you've liked other titles in the series, then it's a no-brainer. As a port, it's very good and runs smoothly (though for me, every time I quit the game, it decided to stop responding; whilst irritating, that's the point of quitting anyway).

However, if you've played Disgaea 2: Cursed Memories or Dark Hero Days, and still own it, I'd suggest waiting until you find this version cheap, perhaps in the Steam Summer Sale; as far as I can tell, there's no brand-new content added exclusively for the PC version. which means that buying it again would simply be a nostalgia trip. In the meantime, I advise you dust down your old PS2 or PSP and play that instead; but If you no longer own those and miss playing it, then Nippon Ichi have produced the perfect solution, for new and returning gamers alike.

To summarize, Disgaea 2 PC does everything the PC port of the first game did, but much better. Apart from including DLCs from all the previous versions of the game - for free, nonetheless - all systems are refined, giving you more combat options and less grinding.
- Every character has a passive ability that gives them something unique, giving you a reason to not just roll with the characters with the best base stats.
-There's special equipment that raises weapon aptitude to S and stat aptitudes to over 100% for each weapon type, making your dreams about gun-toting healers and swordfighting witches a lot more viable! (if you can spare an equipment slot)
-There's a lot more cute monsters this time around! 0w0
- The item world has random Mystery Rooms every few floors and you can cause Dark Courts to appear at certain floors, breaking up the monotony of levelling up items with some bonus rewards, shopping, or minibosses. You even sometimes get a chance to buy Rare and Legendary items, which means you don't need to spend ages looking for a Legendary Cosmic Blade!
-The story is made out of several parallel narratives, which leads to an overall smoother pacing.
- There is no damage from ending a turn lifting an ally, and a stack of characters can do special combo attacks, making the lift/throw system more useful than just quickly moving around.
- There are magical monster weapons now making caster monsters more viable in combat.
-The Demon Rank system is removed, anyone can apply for any Dark Assembly bill... no more need to grind Promotion Exams whenever you want to do something!

And to all of the above, add more secret bosses than ever before and no less than TWO alternate overworlds to unlock (the Dark World and the Land of Carnage) that each adds new challenge to the basic story missions, and you easily have enough content to spend hundreds of hours playing.

I'd like to add that Disgaea is perhaps a fully-aware series (in that it KNOWS it's a series of grinding SRPGs, and that the characters are well aware they are part of an entertainment medium), and I personally enjoy fourth-wall leaning/breaking in games. I should probably also say that there's a lot more to do in Disgaea 2, but the added mechanics of Magichange (monster polymorphing into a weapon), "Toss & Pass" (monster "tossing"), Innocent Towns, Mystery Rooms, and the Land of Carnage just adds on to the amount of things to learn (which is already quite mind-numbing for a newbie before these additions). A great game, as always. The lettering, interface, character portraits, and backgrounds have all been redone to look nice and crisp on modern displays. The same can't be said for the textures and various sprites, however, which really date the game. It would have been trivial, in many cases, to lift character sprites from the newer Disgaea games. Maybe someone will put out a patch (official or otherwise) that will address that.

For those who are going backward to experience an older title in the series for the first time, fair warning: Many of the quality-of-life features from, say, Disgaea 5 aren't present. It's mostly little things, like immediate access to certain information and visual cues, or the ability to reposition your characters without having to completely reset their movement. Other features, like hot-swapping weapons on the fly, were never part of the original game and shouldn't be expected in the PC version. On the other hand, all this is generally improved over the original Disgaea, so there's that.

Mouse control is a little wonky, but functional. You're probably still going to want to play this with a controller, or at least with a combination of keyboard and mouse.

Even without the benefit of nostalgia, I'd recommend this to SRPG fans as a solid title with plenty of tactical variation and innovation.

Disgaea 2 has a special place in my heart since it was the sole reason why I got a psp just to play it back in 2009. In my opinion, if you were to choose between playing the first or second game on steam, I strongly suggest playing this one over the former. Mostly because, I'll be honest here, the first game didn't really age well (especially when compared to later installments in the series) and it feels so archaic playing it after so long. Disgaea 2, on the otherhand, is a game I can always go back to since there's a lot of more content than its predecessor. In terms of story, it's a hit or miss. I personally think it's generic because it just boils down to "main hero has to defeat evil bad guy in order to break a curse" kind of story. Despite the bland story, the characters in Disgaea 2 are actually pretty good!

The main characters this time around are Adell and Rozalin, both of which have great chemistry throughout the story. Not everyone would like Adell since he's pretty bland (i.e. following the chosen one kind of thing) while Rozalin has more character depth and personality throughout the story. I won't spoil anything else about the story since it does have many familiar faces from the first game, as well as a pretty shocking twist for new players, so take my word for it that even though the story isn't great on paper, it does have a satisfying ending.

Now in terms of postgame content, this has A LOT of things to do after the main story. Because, spoilers, the main story only makes up 5% of the actual game! Many things from unlocking the Dark World and conquering it, to fighting hidden boss characters, if you think that the main story wasn't a challenge than these will surely test your patience!

Voice acting wise it's a hit or miss. I personally have no problem with either or. But I sorta like the english dub more since I'm more accustomed to it.

Grinding wise it really isn't that difficult in the main story since Adell has a newb friendly ability (which is to deal more damage against higher level enemies). Postgame on the otherhand, you'll be grinding for DAYS if you want to have a chance to defeat the super boss's the game has to offer.

Disgaea 2 is by far my favorite game of all time. I have probably over 2000 hours on the psp port, and even more on the original, and I still haven't grown bored of it. It's the kind of game you can play for months on end and always have something to do. You have characters to level, weapons to level, skills to level, gear to level, etc. This game is for the grinder at heart that loves to work hard to see numbers rise into seemingly unbelievable heights, but still enjoyable to those that just want to play through the game and be done with it.

The gameplay is challenging, and during your first and second playthough expect to be stopped and forced to grind levels or seriously rethink your strategy numerous times! Once you get a hang of the mechanics it becomes easier, but with the randomly generated maps in the item world, the "stronger enemy" bills you can pass, and the land of carnage(which boosts enemy levels and stats everywhere by 2000%!), expect to always be challenged!

There are 36 generic characters you can create, and over 20 unique characters. Each with thier own unique look and set of skills, passive ability, and weapon proficiency. Anything you can think of, you can make. A sword priest? Sure! Staff warrior? Probably not a good idea, but you can do it! The level cap is 9999, which is not easy to achieve in the slightest, but it doesn't stop there. Base stats and stat per level is based on "stored levels". You give up your gained levels and start at lv1 again to gain bonus stats, and that's what makes your characters truly powerful. And the stored levels cap at 186,000!!! And theres more to it than that, so check the wiki!

Quick list of most of the things to do in this game:
Beat the story mode
Beat the alt. story mode
Get all the endings
Unlock all playable characters in the same run
Unlock all generic characters
Grind levels to 9999(186,000 stored)
Grind character weapon level
Grind gear levels in the item world (30-100 floors per item)
Get felonies on each character to 300(1% bonus xp per felony, more item world stuffs)
Capture "specialists" in the item world to boost weapon stats(up to 19000)
Beat all extra bosses

On the surface it may look like it would be a boring grind, but with so many things to do you can switch goals as SOON as you feel a bit bored of one. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a feeling of accomplishment in completing a goal you worked hard for, cause that's what this game is all about!

Disgaea is always fun to play, regardless which incarnation you turn to. Endless hours of grinding and tongue in cheek humour, always enjoyable. Flipping to an older generation game like this as opposed to D2 or 6, you can definitely see where the game has aged and where theyve made significant strides in the newer games to fix and improve gameplay - it's a lot like getting sucked back in time. This and 1 are also my first times not playing Disgaea on a console like I'm used to.

That said as this is a PC port I expected more from this release with cleanup. I know the game is old but since they made the effort to clean and redo some of the icons and text boxes, etc, why not fix some of the textures like they did in the Disgaea 1 PC port? The images are incredibly blurry during gameplay, the actual sprites have 3 options for texture all of which are pretty bad, and I feel like more could have been done to shine it up a bit. It was jarring for the first few hours until I got too into it to care.

It might be because it's my first Disgaea game using a mouse, but the controls are damn awful on a lot of levels. The more elevation differences there are on a particular map, say in the Item World, the mouse cannot settle on certain areas and jumps erratically. It gives my hand a cramp trying to control things enough so I don't have to re-do them... which doesn't always work because some levels can take ages at a time just for control issues. I'm considering plugging in my PS4 controller for this afterall.

That all said, I'm happy to play it. I hadn't ever played 2 all the way through, and so much and so little has changed over the years, it's like returning to a familiar friend. I do hope they continue to port the rest over so I can play them all on PC as I have on console.
